To be convinced of this, it is merely necessary to glauce at the mosaic which I have just mentioned, or at the miniatures of the Tivoli cartularium. In the latter we see grouped together the Pope, with his pallium over his planeta, and the suburbicarian bishops, with their stoles under the same vestment. Both stoles and pallium are of exactly the same shape and colour, and are orna— mented with the same little black crosses. It is there- fore quite conceivable that whoever wore one of these two insignia might not wear the other.l

In the end, however, a combination of the two was effected. At Ravenna, where a love for decorations was always evinced, we see in the mosaics of San Vitale, Bishop Ecclesius (sixth century) wearing both the priestly stole and the Roman pallium. This picture seems to 106 611 isolated instance,2 the other Bishops of Ravenna, successors of Ecclesius‚ being represented with >the pallium only. Both are seen worn together in a Sacramentary of the ninth century3 from Autun‚ and 011 the paliotto [altar covering] of San Ambrogio of Milan3 and such appears to have been the custom thenceforward among the F rankish clergy.

If we take these facts into consideration, and also the differences and modifications‚ we are thus led to trace the

history of the insignia known under the names pallium, omophorion, 0161111111, stole⁷ and epitrachelion, All have a
